feature.name: daily wage calculator
feature.description: The daily wage calculator is a payroll feature that automatically computes daily pay deductions for employees taking unpaid leave. It calculates daily pay by dividing the employee's total salary (basic plus allowance) by the number of actual working or calendar days in the month, accounting for public holidays. The feature integrates with the leave management system to generate automatic pay deductions that are reflected on the payroll table upon approval of unpaid leave requests. This ensures accurate salary reductions based on the organization's leave policy and holiday calendar. The calculator supports both calendar-day and working-day leave policies.

source_articles_index.title: How is daily pay calculated
source_articles_index.article_summary: This article explains how daily pay is calculated for unpaid leave deductions. It defines the daily pay formula as Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) divided by the number of actual working days in the month. The article clarifies that the leave policy determines whether calculations are based on calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 days), and that public holidays must be deducted from the working days total. Upon approval of an unpaid leave request, an automatic pay deduction is created and reflected on the payroll table. The article includes a worked example showing how public holidays reduce the working days used in the calculation.

source_articles_index.title: Introduction to daily wage calculator
source_articles_index.article_summary: Introduces the Daily Wage Calculator feature, explaining its purpose of providing flexible and customizable daily wage calculations. Describes three calculation bases (calendar days, working days, custom days), salary component selection options, and the feature's impact on salary proration, leave encashment, and unpaid leave deductions. Provides navigation path (Settings → Payroll → Daily Wage Calculation) and identifies authorized user roles (Superadmin, Payroll table managers, transaction processors).

source_articles_index.title: Salary Proration
source_articles_index.article_summary: Explains how Super admins can update salary proration settings in the Daily Wage Calculator (DWC) by navigating to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation and selecting calculation bases (custom days, calendar days, or working days). Salary proration affects employee first salary and end-of-service settlement. Changes apply to all active unpaid payroll amounts. When payroll month is open with existing prorated transactions, Super admin must reject those transactions before saving new proration settings.

procedures.procedure_name: Calculate Daily Pay for Unpaid Leave Deduction
procedures.when_to_use: When an unpaid leave request has been approved and a salary deduction needs to be calculated and applied to the employee's payroll.
steps: Receive and review the unpaid leave request
Approve the unpaid leave request
Identify the organization's leave policy (calendar days or working days)
Determine the total number of days in the policy (e.g., 30 calendar days or 22 working days)
Identify all public holidays falling in the month
Subtract public holidays from the total working days to calculate actual working days
Apply the formula: Daily Pay = Salary Amount (Basic + Allowance) / Actual Working Days
The system automatically creates a pay deduction associated with the unpaid leave request
Verify the deduction is reflected on the payroll table

procedures.when_to_use: When setting up payroll calculations or modifying how daily wages are calculated for your organization.
steps: Navigate to Settings
Select Payroll
Choose Daily Wage Calculation
Select calculation base: calendar days, working days, or custom days
Choose salary components to include in calculations (basic salary, basic salary plus allowances, or allowances only)
Apply configuration

procedures.when_to_use: When configuring how employee salaries should be prorated based on days worked, or when changing calculation bases for first salary and end-of-service settlement calculations
steps: Navigate to Settings > Payroll > Daily wage calculation
Select the required calculation basis: custom days, calendar days, or working days
Save the changes
If payroll month is open and prorated salary transactions exist, reject those transactions before the new proration settings take effect
Resave the proration settings to confirm

rules_limitations_constraints.rule: Daily pay is calculated by dividing the total salary amount (Basic + Allowance) by the number of actual working days in the month. ; The leave policy determines whether calculations are based on calendar days (e.g., 30 days) or working days (e.g., 22 days). ; Public holidays falling in the month must be deducted from the working days total to arrive at the actual working days used in the daily pay calculation. ; An automatic pay deduction is created only upon approval of an unpaid leave request; the deduction is associated with the specific request.

Calendar days calculation: The number of days varies by month (e.g., 31 days in January, 28 days in February). ; Working days calculation: Only business days are counted; weekends and public holidays (configured in company's public holiday calendar) are excluded. ; Custom days calculation: Payroll table managers can set custom calculation bases according to company policies; most UAE and KSA companies use 30 custom days to comply with labor law.
